title: Introduction to Themes
description: A theme file lets you centralize the visual appearance, behavior and intelligence aspects for a chart, gauge, or map.

title: Theme Manager
description: You can choose a theme depending on your aesthetic requirements for the charts, gauges, and maps in your application.

title: Apply a theme to your chart
description: To apply a theme to your chart, include its corresponding JavaScript file in your web page.

title: Use the theme attribute
description: In the following code snippet, you can see how to use the theme attribute to apply a theme:

title: Modify existing themes
description: To modify an existing theme, all you need to do is add/update the required attribute-value pair(s) in the JavaScript file of the theme. You can do this for any number of attributes.

title: Create Your Own Themes
description: FusionCharts Suite XT is shipped with the following three predefined themes zune, ocean and carbon.

title: Create and register multiple themes
description: If you need to create multiple new themes for your application, then ideally you should include all theme definitions in the same file. That way, you will have to include only one .js file in your application, instead of multiple files. You can then change the theme name, as the value of the theme attribute, or as the parameter of the setChartAttribute() method.

title: Include escape characters in theme definition
description: You can include escape characters in definitions for new themes using the same process as the one you follow to include them when modifying existing themes. The process is detailed here.

title: Exporting Charts as Image and PDF
description: A prominent feature is the ability to export the rendered charts in the JPG, PNG, SVG, and PDF formats.

title: Modes of Export
description: FusionCharts Suite XT supports the following three modes of export:

title: Exporting Chart Data
description: FusionCharts lets you export the rendered charts in the JPG, PNG, SVG, and PDF formats. To enable server-side exporting, attribute exportEnabled is set to 1

title: Exporting Charts and Chart Data Using the Server-side Export Feature
description: FusionCharts lets you export the rendered charts in the JPG, PNG, SVG, and PDF formats.

title: Enabling Server-side Export
description: Given below is the brief description of the attributes used to enable server-side exporting:

title: Features of Server-side Exporting
description: Using the server-side mode of exporting ensures that the exported image has exactly the same quality as the image on the web page. This mode ensures a successful export with a public server as well as a private export server that has been set up correctly.

title: Exporting Charts and Chart Data Using the Client-side Export Feature
description: FusionCharts lets you export the rendered charts in the JPG, PNG, SVG, and PDF formats.

title: Exporting Charts and Chart Data Using the Auto Export Feature
description: FusionCharts lets you export the rendered charts in the JPG, PNG, SVG, and PDF formats.

title: Logging Export Statistics
description: FusionCharts Suite XT lets you export your charts and chart data by using one from its three modes of export-server-side export, client-side export, and auto export.

title: Analytics UI for Logging Details
description: The analytics UI has been developed in such a way that the log reports will work in all modern browsers and can be easily consumed by the users. This also helps the administrator to easily keep a tab on the entire volume of exports as well as on individual exports.

title: Logging Architecture
description: The image below shows the architecture of the export statistics logger:

title: Attributes Used for Enabling Logging of Export Statistics
Export Statistics Logged
description: The table below gives a brief description of all the export statistics that are logged:

title: Configuring the Export Feature
description: FusionCharts Suite XT lets you export your charts and chart data by using one from its three modes of export- server-side export, client-side export, and auto export.

title: Experimental Feature Export with Logo Image
description: Currently, using the FusionCharts export handler, when a chart having a custom logo is exported as an image, the logo is not present in the generated image. We are introducing an experimental feature, which allows the logo present in the chart to be exported as well and be displayed in the resultant image.

title: ASP.NET
description: To setup a private export server in ASP.NET, you will need the official ASP.NET export handler provided in the FusionCharts package.

title: How Does It Work?
description: Step 1: A chart is rendered in the browser.

title: Installation
description: Step 1: Unzip the asp-net-export-handler.zip folder in your IIS wwwroot folder (e.g. C:\inetpub\wwwroot).

description: To use the private export server, the following attributes need to be configured correctly in the chart:

title: PHP
description: To setup a private export server in PHP, you will need the official PHP export handle provided in the FusionCharts package.

title: How does it work?
description: Step 1: A chart is rendered in the browser.

title: Installation
description: Step 1: Setup a Linux-based server with administrative access to install the export handler. This is particularly important if you are using a shared hosting service for your web server.

title: Inkscape
description: Inkscape is an open source vector graphics editor. What sets Inkscape apart is its use of Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG), an open XML-based W3C standard, as the native format. Inkscape has a powerful command line interface and can be used in scripts for a variety of tasks, such as exporting and format conversions. For more details, click here.

title: ImageMagick
description: ImageMagick is a free and open-source software suite for displaying, converting, and editing raster image and vector image files. The software mainly consists of a number of command-line interface utilities for manipulating images. For more details, click here.

description: To use the private export server, the following attributes need to be configured correctly in the chart.

title: Configuration
description: The following are the configurables to be modified as required in the config/fusioncharts_exporter.yml:

title: Mount the application
description:
You will have to specify the end point of the export server. In order to do this, you will have to mount the export handler to your rails application. Add the following lines in config/routes.rb:
htmlmount FusionchartsExporter::Engine, at: "<path>"

title: Exporting Multiple Charts in a Single Image
description: This article talks about how to export multiple charts at once and customize them or selectively export charts.

title: Exporting Multiple Charts at Once and Customizing the Exported Charts
description: To demonstrate how multiple charts can be exported in a single image, we've created a sample with four charts. The sample also includes a button that is to be clicked to download the charts in an image.

title: Selectively Exporting Charts
description: The previous sample has four charts—the sales report for Apple products from 2012 to 2015. Let's say that out of these four charts, you need to download only two charts—assume, only the ones for the years 2015 and 2012.

title: Architecture of the FusionCharts Export Server
description: FusionCharts Suite XT lets you export your charts and chart data by using one from its three modes of export- server-side export, client-side export and auto export.

title: Architecture of the FusionCharts Export Server
description: The FusionCharts Export Server is made up of the following three modules:

title: Decoupling of the Converter Module and the Logging Module
description: In the overall architecture of the FusionCharts Export Server, the converter module and the stats logging module have been coupled in a way that decoupling them is easy.

title: Building a Dashboard
description: The consolidated view of having multiple related charts in a page is called a dashboard. This section talks about building a complete dashboard.

title: Building blocks for an effective dashboard
description: Creating a dashboard involves the following steps:

title: What this translates to for you?
description: From a technical perspective, you need to ensure that:

title: Adding the charts to the Dashboard
description: For this example, we will use screenshots and the final dashboard is available to be viewed and edited live at the bottom of the page.

title: Remove an Existing Chart from a Page
description: Chart objects created as part of FusionCharts Suite XT support the dispose method, this completely cleans the memory space and all references to the chart and its data are removed.

title: Get Reference to Chart Object
description: FusionCharts Suite XT supports 3 ways of getting references to the chart object at runtime. This reference comes in handy if you want to perform operations on the chart

title: Using the FusionCharts Constructor
description: The FusionCharts constructor returns a reference to the id of the chart passed to it when it is called without the new keyword.

title: Using the Items Object
description: When the FusionCharts library is used and charts are rendered on a page, an items object contains references to all the charts used in the page. The FusionCharts items object returns a reference to the id of the chart passed to it.

title: FusionCharts Constructor and Object
description: All of the charts and maps are constructed using the constructor provided by FusionCharts which accepts a JSON object of chart properties.

title: Creating charts using the FusionCharts Constructor
description: The FusionCharts constructor accepts a JSON object whose properties are as follows:

title: Accessing already created chart using FusionCharts Constructor
description: We saw above how to build a FusionCharts object by passing a JSON object of chart properties to its constructor. What if we have already constructed the FusionCharts object and want to refer to that same object? Let us see how this works by considering a simple example:

title: Invoking APIs using instance of FusionCharts
description: We saw above how we can create instance of FusionCharts and also how we can reference an existing FusionCharts instance. The snippets shown in the above sections contained code where some APIs like render(), getJSONData() were invoked using the FusionCharts instance. In this section we will see more such APIs in action.

title: Managing Synchronization when Rendering Multiple Charts
description: When the render() function is called to render a chart on a page, it sets into motion the following actions for each chart:

title: Change Chart Properties at Runtime
description: This section shows you how you can change properties once the chart has been drawn.

title: Changing height and width of the chart
description: Once you have initialized a chart, you can change the dimensions, at the client-side, through a JavaScript API using the resizeTo() method.

title: Changing chart type
description: FusionCharts Suite XT makes it simple for you to change chart types using the 'chartType()' method. This method lets you convert from one chart type to another (as long as its the same type of data e.g., single-series).

title: Changing Chart properties
description: FusionCharts Suite XT makes it simple for you to change properties of a chart at the 'chart' level like Caption, Sub-Caption, Fonts, Themes etc using the 'setChartAttribute' method.

title: Color Range
description: This section talks about the color range used by the charts to represent a range of data values.

title: Two range partially overlap
description: Let's take the same examples and see what happens when two range partially overlaps. For instance, the color range is defined as shown below:

title: Two range completely Overlap
description: Now, let's take the same examples and see what happens when two range completely overlaps. For instance, the color range is defined as shown below:

title: Same max value of two range
description: Now let's check what happens if two range has the same max value. For instance, the color range is defined as shown below:

title: Same min value of two range
description: Now let's check what happens if two range has the same minimum value. For instance, the color range is defined as shown below:

title: Values not belonging to any range
description: Now let's check what happens if there is a value which does not belong to any of the range. For instance, the color range is defined as shown below:

title: Using Special Characters
description: FusionCharts Suite supports all unicode characters as part of charts. You can use Multi Lingual text, Currency symbols as well as special characters as part of your charts.

title: Using Multi Lingual Text
description: FusionCharts XT allows you to use multi-lingual (UTF-8) characters on the charts.

title: Using currency symbols
description: Currency symbols like the, £(Pound), €(Euro), ¥(Yen) etc., may also be a part of the data which is displayed on charts. To display these characters on a chart, you can simply include it in the XML/JSON data source of the chart. This is applicable in both Data URL and Data String methods.

title: Using special characters
description: You can directly embed most of the special characters and punctuation marks in the XML/JSON data source of your chart. However some characters like & , < , > , ' (apostrophe) and " (quote) need to be specially encoded when providing the same as a part of the chart data. Apart from this, there is no need to encode any other special character.

title: Plot Discontinuous Data
description: FusionCharts XT lets you do this very easily, just leaving the value attribute blank will do the trick.

title: Connecting Null Data
description: In our above Line chart, we were showing a break for the months of May and June. If you do not want to show this break for May and Jun, and want April to directly connect to July, you can do so using the connectNullData attribute.

title: Highlight Specific Data Points
description: To help user visualize data, it is often necessary for you to highlight one or more data points in a chart.

title: Changing the Color of an Individual Data Point
description: A plot with a distinctly different color stands out of a set of uniformly colored data plots. This is the easiest and most prominent way to highlight a data plot. But, this technique fails in case different colors are used on different data plots.

title: Highlighting the Data Point by changing its Alpha and using Dashed Border
description: This is a more subtle way to highlight a data plot, where you may not prefer to colorize the plot with a distinctly different color. Change the plot opacity and you get a color derivative of the original color. If thats not enough as a highlighter, make the border dashed to add weight and help the plot stand out in the show.

title: Changing Anchor Properties in charts like Line and Area
description: Anchors represent data points in charts that lack data plots to represent numerical data. Charts plotting line or area or both (as in combination charts) fall in this category. Spline charts fall in this category either. In a nutshell, if you have line, spline or area plots in any chart and you need to highlight data points on any of these, use anchors if not yet and highlight the required data plot.

title: View Data of Existing Chart
description: This guide will show you how you can get tabular data from a chart and display it as a table alongside it.

title: Get Formatted Numbers Outside Chart
description: FusionCharts number formatter module lets you format data, you can get this data even outside the chart area.

title: Reuse the number format used in the chart on page
description: Number formatting is by default active in all charts. Reuse this format in your page by simply invoking the API as below.

title: Use FusionCharts library in the page to specify the number format required
description: You may use FusionCharts library to format number even if you are not rendering a chart using FusionCharts Suite XT in your page. Just include fusioncharts.js in your page and you are ready to format numbers in your page using the number formatter API.

title: Get SVG Representation of a Chart
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT you can easily get the SVG string of any chart using the getSVGString method. Shown below is a chart that displays the SVG string of a chart

title: Configure Chart Messages
description: This section talks about the messeges which are displayed at the time of rendering of the chart. You can add cosmetics for those messages as well.

title: Setting custom messages
description: A simple column 2D chart that displays custom dataLoadStartMessage is shown below:

title: Styling chart messages
description: Custom styles can also be applied to these messages, i.e. setting custom text font, font-size and color.

title: Render Thumbnail Versions of Charts
description: This section talks about render a chart in thumbnail version, which is use when space is a limitation.

title: Render Plots shedding all other Chart elements
description: A chart is composed of a host of elements. The general elements and how to hide them is tabulated as below.

description: Charts have varying interactive feature. However some of these interactivities are common across the suite. The following table summarise the common ones.

title: Static Presentation of Chart
description: An image type presentation makes it necessary to be visually static. Some of the required measures in this context are given below.

title: Handling Events
description: To configure events for charts, you need to, decide the event you want to configure and the response you want when it is triggered and create an event listener that listens for the event being triggered and executes the required response.

title: Defining the Listener Function
description: To configure the renderComplete event for the column 2D chart, first define the listener function for the event in the JSON/XML code for the chart.

title: Listening to Events Triggered for All Charts on a Page
description: Events can be attached to the windows.FusionCharts object. Attaching events to the FusionCharts constructor causes the event listener to be attached to all the charts on a page-the ones that are already created as well as the ones that will be created later.

title: Listening to Multiple Events Triggered for One Chart
description: To listen to multiple events for one chart using just one event listener, use the code snippet shown below:

title: Cancelling Event Listeners
description: The preventDefault() function is used to cancel the execution of the listener function of an event. The function is used with the eventObj parameter—eventObj.preventDefault()—of the listener function.

title: Removing Event Listeners
description: To curb needless memory consumption by charts on a page, it is advisable to remove all event listeners that are not required.
